The internet giants of 2030 won't be built on apps, clicks, or transactions.

And they won't win by harvesting attention or purchases. They'll be built on something far more valuable:

They'll win by becoming your intimate AI companion for life's most important decisions.

This isn't theoretical. Quietly there are companies building "trusted recommender" platforms that combine discovery, intent, and ongoing relationships.

Imagine your AI relationship manager understands every user's complete context and preferences, maintaining perfect memory of their journey, engaging exactly when and how they prefer.

Your vertical agent transforms basic interactions into deep relationships across dating, styling, and financeâ€“evolving from initial pain point to lifetime trust.

Your recommender system analyzes millions of data points across individual, aggregate, and industry levels, building compounding advantages that traditional platforms can't match.

Your trust engine converts single transactions into ongoing relationships, turning a dating match into relationship guidance, a style pick into wardrobe evolution, a mortgage into complete financial planning

Your vertical AI extends beyond the hero product, managing thousands of personalized journeys simultaneously, each one deepening trust through continuous engagement.

Your relationship builder spots adjacent needs before users express them, automatically expanding into complementary services while maintaining earned trust.

The entire discovery-to-relationship loop becomes automated, working 24/7 on trust-building.

The economics are devastating: what once took thousands of employees and billions in infrastructure now happens through AI at the cost of inference.

One trusted recommender becomes as powerful as an entire traditional platform.

User trust becomes compounding.

Relationship expansion becomes systematic

Winners will be whoever builds the richest vertical-specific data, whoever earns genuine user trust first, and whoever can extend relationships beyond the initial transaction.

While you sleep, it's building relationships with millions

While you scale linearly, it's compounding trust exponentially

While you fight for attention, it's making switching impossible

They're about to eat every consumer vertical: dating apps become lifetime relationship guides style platforms become aesthetic architects mortgage tools become wealth builders.

The next giants won't win through user growth they'll win by becoming irreplaceable companions.

This isn't about better AI it's about trust at infinite scale.

Adoption is temporary trust is forever.

Paul DelSignore
Paul DelSignore
posts.content:
I wonder if it is helpful to use the term 'AI Agents' to refer to AI autonomous applications.

This terminology personifies AI, and some platforms have also adopted phrases like 'hiring' AI agents into the workflow process. I've even heard someone in a podcast mention that IT will become the new HR for companies.

This obviously creates a level of concern and panic in the workforce, as personifying AI also means perceiving AI as replacements for employees.

I suppose 'Agentic applications' or 'Agentic workflows' are okay because they keep the focus on programmatic processes, but AI agents suggest that AI operates with human-like intent.

I'm not denying that AI will replace certain tasks or roles, and perhaps raising awareness is necessary, but referring to AI as agents by anthropomorphizing them feels unnecessarily alarming to me.

What do you think?

Autonomy is often misunderstood as a future without humans.The rise of Autonomy does not diminish the role of humans - it transforms.

Operators become orchestrators, focusing on strategy and oversight rather than manual tasks. Our challenge as leaders is to create a culture where technology empowers, not replaces and accountability remains at the core.

As usual, my take is from a business value perspective. 

No doubt that the 'agentic mesh' is key. According to my handy dandy AI buddy,, McKinsey predicts AI could add $4.4 trillion annually to the global economy - and other respected entities are even bolder in their predictions.

I do get worried with all the "Just add AI" convos I see, though. The truth is that the first step is easy, so it's table stakes - a digital lift and shift of make-work from humans to tech. No big deal. . . we've been doing that for decades. The doubling of productivity is all the proof point we need.

The next level of value is at the edges:

1. getting good, timely, complete, contextual data to and from the nodes, and
2. rethinking processes dynamically so that they support maximum value over time

- all while driving a minimum 250% ROI and minimizing risk/cost

*This* is where the hard work lies - and where the real value is unlocked.

The real value in AI requires timely and contextual data, dynamic process rethinking, and achieving meaningful ROI, as you point out. 

No doubt, this is where the hard work lies. But thereâ€™s also tangible & significant business value being realized today with Industrial AIâ€”and itâ€™s distinct from the more traditional GenAI use cases.

The transformative leap happens when we focus on ensuring timely, complete, and actionable data flows between nodes, all supported by governance frameworks that drive sustainable ROI. Your point about rethinking processes dynamically is key. In my carousel, I touched on how edge orchestration and agentic AI are enabling this, paving the way for intelligent, adaptive operations.
